[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â also Demetrius on Style.Fyfe, W. Hamilton, and Roberts, W. Rhys, eds. and trans. Aristotle, The Poetics; "Longinus": On the Sublime; Demetrius, On Style. [1927.] Revised edition. London: Heinemann, 1932. This Loeb Classical Library edition (originally published in 1927) brought together Fyfe's new translations of Aristotle and Longinus with Roberts's well established 1902 translation of Demetrius.Â
[blank] Â XÂ MM takes notes on Fyfe's "Introduction" to Aristotle and Longinus on this and the next page.Even Aristotle was catholic enough to maintain that "the many" are better
[blank]Â Â Â Â judges of poetry than the expert few.Â Â Â IX In the 5th c. their "ethical twist" puts
[blank]Â Â Â Â them out of court as literary critics.Â Â Â X Plato is the first Greek who
[blank]Â Â Â Â really graduated in literary criticism. He valued art for its moral effect on
[blank]Â Â Â Â conduct . . . But he valued it too for its own sake.
[blank]Â Â Â | [The artistâs] power is a spiritual magnetism . . . . . this fascinationâaÂ
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â ÏÏ ÏÎ±Î³ÏÎ³Î¯Î± or conjuring of the soulâis the object of Art.MM cites these phrases in "Feeling and Precision" (Prose 398). Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Plato
[blank]Â Â Â Â Wonderful creatures, these poets, but out they must go. They endanger the ideals
[blank]Â Â Â Â of citizenship . . . . ."Art does not deal in truth. It is 3 removes fr. truth."
[blank]Â Â . . . . What do we want with an imitation of an imitation? And in the Phaedrusâ
[blank]Â Â Â Â where his enthus. for literature is not concealed . . . books are unsatisfactory,
[blank]Â Â Â Â because they you canât cross-examine them. "They go on saying the same thing
[blank]Â Â Â Â over and over."
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â It is this view that Aristotle combats, finding the answer in
[blank]Â Â Â Â Platoâs own mouth. It is not the "particulars" of sense that Art
[blank]Â Â Â Â represents but "universal" Truths,âthe inner interpretation of
[blank]Â Â Â Â the mind . . . . . So Poetry is not 3 removes fr. truth: it comes nearer
[blank]Â Â Â Â the truth than any other human process, since it records "not what
[blank]Â Â Â Â did happen but what would happen." and Poetics ch. IX Â§1
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â humanÂ
[blank]Â Â Â Â and disentangles from incidents the principles on which life works.Â
[blank]Â Â Â Â The truth of art is higher than the truth of fact.
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â . . .Â
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Of course Â Â Â emotions are dangerous . . . . but Art is their medicalÂ
[blank]Â Â Â Â outlet (ÎºÎ¬Î¸Î±ÏÏÎ¹Ï)Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â not
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â That oneâs emotions can be stirred by the facts of life but by their
[blank]Â Â Â artistic representation seems to have been Aristotles own discovery.
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â what makes it diffÂ
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Also his treatment of style: a poem is diff. from prose . . . Not only the metre
[blank]Â Â Â but the vocabulary. âStrange wordsâ a mixture of strange and ordinaryÂ

lg.l: [blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Fyfe, âIntroduction.â Fyfe and Roberts, Poetics (see earlier note).Â And it is the same with "plot" 1 A plot must have unity be one

[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 3 hero must be "heroic" & cause his fate but not deserve it.
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 4 chorus must play its part, psychology must be subordinate to plot
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â His conclusions are impeccable but they allow the crudest
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â melodrama to rank with the Oedipus Tyrannus & above the Agamemnon.
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â That the Gr. tragedians were prophets he seems unaware
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â not a hint that Tragedy arose as a means of interpreting history the
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â saga stories in the light of a later morality.
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â . . . . His dissection discovers all the great first principles
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â except the principle of life.
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â XVIÂ All rules for writing are rules for writing badlyâ
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â the supreme quality is infecting with his audience w. enthusiasm
[blank]Â Â Â Â XVIIÂ Â This supreme quality âLonginusâ possesses. Gibbon in his
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Journal: Till now, I was acquainted only with 2 ways of
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â criticizing a beautiful passage, . . . to show by exact anatomy whence
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â they had sprung; the other an idle exclamation or encomium
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Longinus has shown me that there is a third. He tells
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â me his own feelings upon reading it,â& tells them with
[blank] ENERGYÂ such energy that he communicates them.
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (á¼ÎºÏÏÏÎ¹Ï)Â expression of a forceful human character
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Just as fine glass or well cast iron rings true to the stroke,
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â so grandeur or sublimity in art gives the unmistakable
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â âringâ of a great soul. Style is the shadow of a personality.â
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â The chief means by which personality can thus be expressed
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â are beautiful words, but . . . . sincerity is essential, a mind full
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â of meaning
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Longinus: The one essential is genuine feeling
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â . . . here is a critic who makes it clear at that lit. is a function
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â of life and that those who, having something to say, have learnt
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â how to say it create a revelation as sweet to the world as the making
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â of it is to them.Â

[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â poetry seems to owe its origins to 2 causes
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 1 an instinct for representation

[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â for tune & rhythm
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â (metres are sections of rhythms

[blank]Â Â 21 Â Â tragedy tends to fall within a single revolution of the sun

[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â the elements of tragedy are not all present in the epic.Â
[blank] p. 23Â Â Aristotle, Poetics. Fyfe and Roberts, Poetics (see earlier note). Tragedy is, then, a representation of an action that is heroic
[blank]Â Â Â Â and complete and of a certain magnitude . . . it represents
[blank]Â Â Â Â men in action & does not use narrative, & through
[blank]Â Â Â Â pity and FEAR it effects relief to these & similar emotions.
[blank]Â Â Â Â the essential part is the spectacular effect, song-making & diction
[blank]Â Â Â Â By "diction" I mean here the metrical arrangement of the words;
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â characterÂ
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dictionÂ Â Â

[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â spectacleÂ Â Â but of a piece of action
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â songÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â & and while character

[blank]Â Â Â Â or the opposite.

lg.l: [blank]Â Â Â 33Â Â Â Aristotle, Poetics. Fyfe and Roberts, Poetics (see earlier note).as for the natural limit of the action, the longer the better as
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â far as magnitude goes, provided it can all be grasped at once.
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â To give a simple definition: the magnitude which admits of a change
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â from bad fortune to good or from good fortune to bad, in a sequence
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â of events which follow one another either inevitably or according
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â to probability, that is the proper limit.
[blank]Â Â Â Â 33Â Â A plot does not have unity â¦ because it deals w. a single hero.
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â . . . Homer constructed his Odyssey round a single ACTION
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â representÂ
[blank] The Plot must a single piece of ACTION and the WHOLE of it
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â if the presence or absence of a thing makes no visible diff., then it is not
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â an integral part of the whole.
[blank]Â Â Â Â 9|.Â a poetâs object is not to tell what actually happened but what could or
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â would happen either probably or inevitably.
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a historian tells what happenedÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â gives particular facts
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a poetÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â "Â Â might happenÂ Â Â Â Â gives general truths
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Even if he represents what actually happened,
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â he is none the less a poet, for there is nothing to prevent some actual
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â occurrences being the sort of thing that would probably or inevitably happen.
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â simpleÂ
[blank]Â Â Â 37Â Â Of plots & actions, the worst are those which are "episodic" in which
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â the episodes do not follow probably or inevitably
[blank] (Bad poets) (they strain a plot beyond its capacity & sacrifice continuity.
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â fear & pity result most of all when the incidents are unexpected
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â & yet one is a consequence of the other.
[blank]Â Â Â Â 41Â Â A "reversal" is a change of the situation into the opposite
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â the man in the Lynceus led off to execution & Danaus following
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â to kill him, & instead the latter killed & the former escaped
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â [Haman in the BibleIn the Book of Esther, Haman's plot to have the Jews killed by Ahasuerus is foiled by Esther and Haman is himself executed.]
[blank]Â Â Â Â 41Â Â A "discovery" is a change from ignorance to knowledge.Â
[blank] 43Â Â Aristotle, Poetics. Fyfe and Roberts, PoeticsÂ (see earlier note).Constituent parts,âPrologue, Episode, Exode, Choral Songâ
[blank]Â Â Â Â These are common to all tragedies.
[blank] 45Â Â one shld not show worthy men passing fr. good fortune to bad
[blank]Â Â Â Â That shocks our feelings.
[blank]Â Â Â Â Nor wicked people passing from bad fortune to good (that is
[blank]Â Â Â Â the most untragic of all, . . . it does not satisfy our feeling, orÂ
[blank]Â Â Â Â arouse pityâor fear.
[blank]Â Â Â Â Nor a bad man from good fortune to bad fortune
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â nor would we then feelÂ
[blank]Â Â Â Â (for we donât feel pity for the undeserved misfortune,Â â¸ fear for the man like ourselves
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â There remains then the meanâthe man not pre-eminently virtuous or just
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â who yet through no badness or villainy of his own falls into
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â misfortune
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â must be due to some great flaw in such a man
[blank] 49Â Â The plot should be so constructed that even without seeing the play
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â anyone hearing of the incidents, thrills with fear and pity.
[blank] 51Â Â 1. The action may happen consciously & knowing the facts
[blank]Â Â Â Â 2. they may do the deed not realizing the horror of it (Oedipus)
[blank]Â Â Â Â 3. intend to do some irremediable action in ignorance & to discover the truth before
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â doing it. (Best of all)
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â 1. the char. should be goodÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â or clever.Â
[blank] 55Â Â 2. the Characters must be in keepingânot appropr. for a woman to be manly
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â 4. consistent (even consistently inconsistent)
[blank] 65Â Â Keep the scene before the eyes. Amphiaraos was made
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â to rise from a temple . . . was a failure since the audience objected.Â

lg.l: [blank]Â Â 65Â Â Aristotle, Poetics. Fyfe and Roberts, Poetics (see earlier note).And that is why poetry needs either a sympathetic nature
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â or a madman, the former being impressionable and the latter inspired
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â the stories
[blank]Â Â 65Â Â should be first sketched in outline . . 67 Not till this is
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â done should you put in names and insert episodes.
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â The story of the Odyssey is quite short. A man is for many years away
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â from home and his footsteps are dogged by Poseidon and he is all alone.
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â Moreover, affairs at home are in such a state that his estate is being wasted by suitors &
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â a plot laid against his son, but after being storm-tossed he
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â arrives, reveals who he is attacks them, is saved and destroys
[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â his enemies. . . . .Â The rest is episodes.
[blank]Â Â 67Â Â In every tragedy there is a complication & a denouement

[blank]Â Â Â Â Â Â should be mastered.
